speaker: Doctor
text: So, you've been experiencing shortness of breath, increased abdominal girth, and a large ovarian mass. Can you tell me when these symptoms first started?

speaker: Patient
text: It's been about a month now, I'd say. I remember it started with just feeling a bit winded after my usual walks, and then my clothes started feeling tighter around the waist.

speaker: Doctor
text: Over the past few months, I've noticed that my breathing gets a bit harder when I'm doing simple tasks, and my stomach has been getting bigger. The ovarian mass, I've had it for as long as I can remember, but it's been getting bigger too.

speaker: Patient
text: It's been really hard to keep up with my teaching schedule, I have to stop to catch my breath even after just walking from one classroom to the next. And I've noticed that my clothes are getting tighter around the middle, but I just thought it was from eating too much.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any significant weight gain recently, or is the increased abdominal girth more of a gradual change?

speaker: Patient
text: To be honest, I haven't really noticed a significant weight gain, but I do feel like my clothes are fitting differently. I've been wearing the same size for years, but now my pants are feeling a bit tighter around the waist.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've noticed that you have a bit of a difficult time breathing when you're speaking, can you tell me if you've experienced any pain or discomfort in your abdomen or lower back when you're experiencing shortness of breath?

speaker: Patient
text: It's mostly just a feeling of pressure, but sometimes it gets a bit sharper when I take deep breaths.

speaker: Doctor
text: You've had the ovarian mass since you can remember, but it's been growing lately. Have you noticed any changes in your bowel movements or urination patterns?

speaker: Patient
text: To be honest, I haven't really noticed any changes in my bowel movements or urination patterns. I still go to the bathroom at the same time every day, and my bowel movements are pretty regular.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any vaginal bleeding or discharge related to the ovarian mass, or is it painless?

speaker: Patient
text: No, there's no pain associated with it, and I haven't noticed any bleeding or discharge, but I do get a bit of a sensation when I move around. It's hard to describe, but it's like there's something shifting inside.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you had any family history of ovarian cancer or any other types of cancer?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I don't think so. My mother passed away from a heart condition when I was a teenager, but I don't recall anyone in my family having cancer.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've noticed that your breathing does seem a bit labored, and your abdomen does appear to be distended. Can you tell me if you've experienced any nausea or vomiting with your shortness of breath?

speaker: Patient
text: To be honest, I haven't experienced any nausea or vomiting, but I do feel a bit queasy when I'm doing physical activities. It's hard to describe, but it's like my body is just really tired.

speaker: Doctor
text: You've mentioned that the ovarian mass has been growing lately, but you've had it since you were a child. Have you ever had any surgical procedures or treatments for the mass in the past?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I've never had any surgeries or treatments for it. I've just kind of gotten used to it being there, and it's never caused me any problems until recently, when it started to feel like it's taking up more space.

speaker: Doctor
text: You mentioned that the ovarian mass has been growing lately, but it's been with you since you were a child. Can you tell me if you've noticed any changes in your menstrual cycle, such as heavier or lighter periods?

speaker: Patient
text: Honestly, my periods have always been pretty irregular, but I think they've been getting a bit lighter over the past few months. I'm not really sure, to be honest.

speaker: Doctor
text: You've had the ovarian mass since you were a child, but it's been growing lately. Have you noticed any unusual sensations or feelings in your pelvis or lower back when you're sitting or standing for long periods of time?

speaker: Patient
text: It's hard to describe, but sometimes I get a bit of a dull ache in my lower back when I'm sitting for a while. It's not too bad, but it's definitely there.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've noticed that your abdominal girth seems to be more pronounced on one side. Is the ovarian mass located on one side of your pelvis, or is it more centrally located?

speaker: Patient
text: Yes, I think it's located more on the left side of my pelvis. I'm not really sure, it's just kind of always been there, but I do feel like it's shifted a bit over the past few months.

speaker: Doctor
text: So the ovarian mass has been with you since you were a child, but it's only been growing lately. Have you experienced any changes in your body temperature or night sweats?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I don't think so. I just feel really tired all the time, and my body feels like it's just really working hard to do even simple things.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any changes in your energy levels or fatigue, even when you're not experiencing shortness of breath?

speaker: Patient
text: To be honest, I've been feeling really exhausted lately, even when I'm just sitting at my desk or doing simple tasks. It's like my body is just running on empty, and I need to take breaks all the time. I've been relying on coffee just to get through the day, which is not like me at all.

speaker: Doctor
text: So you've had the ovarian mass since you were a child, but it's only been growing lately. That's a crucial piece of information. Can you tell me if you've ever noticed any unusual lumps or swelling in your neck, armpits, or groin area?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I don't think so. I haven't noticed any unusual lumps or swelling in those areas. It's just been the ovarian mass and the shortness of breath that I've been noticing.

speaker: Doctor
text: So the ovarian mass has been with you since you were a child, but it's only been growing lately. That's a crucial piece of information. Can you tell me if you've experienced any dizziness or lightheadedness when you're standing up or changing positions?

speaker: Patient
text: Yes, I have been feeling a bit dizzy when I stand up too quickly, but I just thought it was because I wasn't getting enough rest.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note of your long history with the ovarian mass, but the recent growth and increased abdominal girth are concerning. Have you noticed any recent changes in your urination frequency or difficulty urinating?

speaker: Patient
text: To be honest, I don't think so. I still go to the bathroom at the same time every day, and I don't have any trouble urinating. It's just been the shortness of breath and the feeling of pressure in my abdomen that's been really bothering me lately.

speaker: Doctor
text: So, the ovarian mass has been with you since you were a child, but it's only been growing lately. Have you ever had any pelvic exams or ultrasounds performed on the mass in the past?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I've never had any ultrasounds or pelvic exams done on the mass before. I've just kind of gotten used to it being there and never thought much of it until it started growing and causing problems.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you ever had any previous diagnoses or concerns about the ovarian mass that were dismissed or not followed up on?

speaker: Patient
text: Honestly, my pediatrician used to tell me it was just a cyst, and I was too young to have any further tests done. I think I was around 10 or 11 years old when I first mentioned it to her.

speaker: Doctor
text:
I've asked all 20 questions, now it's time to make a diagnosis. Based on your symptoms and history, I'm going to take a calculated risk. 

However, I do want to request one more piece of information before making a final decision. REQUEST TEST: CA-125 blood test.

Please note, I'm aware of the recent case where a doctor with similar symptoms was diagnosed with cancer, and I'm trying to be thorough in my diagnosis.
